segment.source: How to Configure the Server to be Trusted for Delegation
segment.target: How to Configure the Server to be Trusted for Delegation

segment.source: How to Configure the Server to be Trusted for Delegation
segment.target: How to Configure the Server to be Trusted for Delegation

segment.source: How to Configure the Server to be Trusted for Delegation
segment.target: How to Configure the Server to be Trusted for Delegation

segment.source: When you install the Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) Management Server software, you can choose to install it by using a distributed system architecture.
segment.target: When you install the Microsoft Application Virtualization (App-V) Management Server software, you can choose to install it by using a distributed system architecture.

segment.source: If you install the console, the Management Web Service, and the database on different computers, you must configure the Internet Information Services (IIS) server to be trusted for delegation.
segment.target: If you install the console, the Management Web Service, and the database on different computers, you must configure the Internet Information Services (IIS) server to be trusted for delegation.

segment.source: This is necessary because the Management Web Service will attempt to connect to the App-V data store by using the credentials of the App-V administrator who is using the console.
segment.target: This is necessary because the Management Web Service will attempt to connect to the App-V data store by using the credentials of the App-V administrator who is using the console.

segment.source: The database server on which the data store is installed will not accept the administrator’s credentials from the IIS server unless the IIS server is configured to be trusted for delegation, and so the Management Web Service will not be able to connect to the App-V data store.
segment.target: The database server on which the data store is installed will not accept the administrator’s credentials from the IIS server unless the IIS server is configured to be trusted for delegation, and so the Management Web Service will not be able to connect to the App-V data store.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: If you install the App-V Management Server software on a single server and place the data store on a separate server, there is one situation in which you must still configure the server to be trusted for delegation even though the Management Web Service and Management Console are on the same server.
segment.target: If you install the App-V Management Server software on a single server and place the data store on a separate server, there is one situation in which you must still configure the server to be trusted for delegation even though the Management Web Service and Management Console are on the same server.

segment.source: This situation occurs if you need to connect to the Management Web Service in the console by using the Use Alternate Credentials option.
segment.target: This situation occurs if you need to connect to the Management Web Service in the console by using the Use Alternate Credentials option.

segment.source: The type of delegation that you can use depends on the Domain Functional Level that you have configured in your Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) infrastructure.
segment.target: The type of delegation that you can use depends on the Domain Functional Level that you have configured in your Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS) infrastructure.

segment.source: The following table lists the types of delegation that can be configured for each Domain Functional Level for App-V.
segment.target: The following table lists the types of delegation that can be configured for each Domain Functional Level for App-V.

segment.source: Detailed instructions follow the table.
segment.target: Detailed instructions follow the table.

segment.source: Domain Functional Level
segment.target: Domain Functional Level

segment.source: Delegation Levels Available
segment.target: Delegation Levels Available

segment.source: Windows 2000 native
segment.target: Windows 2000 native

segment.source: No delegation (default)
segment.target: No delegation (default)

segment.source: Unconstrained delegation
segment.target: Unconstrained delegation

segment.source: Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Server 2008 R2
segment.target: Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Server 2008 R2

segment.source: No delegation (default)
segment.target: No delegation (default)

segment.source: Unconstrained delegation¹
segment.target: Unconstrained delegation¹

segment.source: Constrained delegation (Use Kerberos Only Protocols)
segment.target: Constrained delegation (Use Kerberos Only Protocols)

segment.source: Constrained delegation (Use any authentication protocol) ¹
segment.target: Constrained delegation (Use any authentication protocol) ¹

segment.source: ¹ Not recommended.
segment.target: ¹ Not recommended.

segment.source: To configure unconstrained delegation when the Domain Functional Level is Windows 2000 native
segment.target: To configure unconstrained delegation when the Domain Functional Level is Windows 2000 native

segment.source: On the domain controller for your Web server’s domain, complete the following steps.
segment.target: On the domain controller for your Web server’s domain, complete the following steps.

segment.source: Click Start, Administrative Tools, and then click Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: Click Start, Administrative Tools, and then click Active Directory Users and Computers.

segment.source: Expand domain, and then expand the Computers folder.
segment.target: Expand domain, and then expand the Computers folder.

segment.source: In the right pane, right-click the computer name for the Web server, and then click Properties.
segment.target: In the right pane, right-click the computer name for the Web server, and then click Properties.

segment.source: On the General tab, ensure that the Trust computer for delegation check box is selected.
segment.target: On the General tab, ensure that the Trust computer for delegation check box is selected.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: To configure unconstrained delegation when the Domain Functional Level is Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Server 2008 R2
segment.target: To configure unconstrained delegation when the Domain Functional Level is Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Server 2008 R2

segment.source: On the domain controller for your Web server’s domain, complete the following steps.
segment.target: On the domain controller for your Web server’s domain, complete the following steps.

segment.source: Click Start, click Administrative Tools, and then click Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: Click Start, click Administrative Tools, and then click Active Directory Users and Computers.

segment.source: Expand domain, and expand the Computers folder.
segment.target: Expand domain, and expand the Computers folder.

segment.source: In the right pane, right-click the computer name for the Web server, select Properties, and then click the Delegation tab.
segment.target: In the right pane, right-click the computer name for the Web server, select Properties, and then click the Delegation tab.

segment.source: Click to select Trust this computer for delegation to any service (Kerberos only).
segment.target: Click to select Trust this computer for delegation to any service (Kerberos only).

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: To configure constrained delegation when the Domain Functional Level is Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Server 2008 R2
segment.target: To configure constrained delegation when the Domain Functional Level is Windows Server 2003, Windows Server 2008, or Windows Server 2008 R2

segment.source: On the domain controller for your Web server’s domain, complete the following steps.
segment.target: On the domain controller for your Web server’s domain, complete the following steps.

segment.source: Click Start, click Administrative Tools, and then click Active Directory Users and Computers.
segment.target: Click Start, click Administrative Tools, and then click Active Directory Users and Computers.

segment.source: Expand domain, and then expand the Computers folder.
segment.target: Expand domain, and then expand the Computers folder.

segment.source: In the right pane, right-click the computer name for the Web server, select Properties, and then click the Delegation tab.
segment.target: In the right pane, right-click the computer name for the Web server, select Properties, and then click the Delegation tab.

segment.source: Click to select Trust this computer for delegation to specified services only.
segment.target: Click to select Trust this computer for delegation to specified services only.

segment.source: Ensure that Use Kerberos only is selected, and then click OK.
segment.target: Ensure that Use Kerberos only is selected, and then click OK.

segment.source: Click the Add button.
segment.target: Click the Add button.

segment.source: In the Add Services dialog box, click Users or Computers, and then browse to or type the name of the Microsoft SQL server that has the App-V data store and is to receive the users credentials from IIS.
segment.target: In the Add Services dialog box, click Users or Computers, and then browse to or type the name of the Microsoft SQL server that has the App-V data store and is to receive the users credentials from IIS.

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: In the Available Services list, select the MSSQLSvc service that lists port number on which the Microsoft SQL Server is accepting connections for the App-V database (the default port is 1433).
segment.target: In the Available Services list, select the MSSQLSvc service that lists port number on which the Microsoft SQL Server is accepting connections for the App-V database (the default port is 1433).

segment.source: Click OK.
segment.target: Click OK.

segment.source: Additional steps to configure IIS 7 for constrained delegation
segment.target: Additional steps to configure IIS 7 for constrained delegation

segment.source: If you are running the Management Web Service on an IIS 7 server, you must complete the following steps to set the IIS 7 useAppPoolCredentials variable to True.
segment.target: If you are running the Management Web Service on an IIS 7 server, you must complete the following steps to set the IIS 7 useAppPoolCredentials variable to True.

segment.source: Open an elevated Command Prompt window.
segment.target: Open an elevated Command Prompt window.

segment.source: To open an elevated Command Prompt window, click Start, click All Programs, click Accessories, right-click Command Prompt, and then click Run as administrator.
segment.target: To open an elevated Command Prompt window, click Start, click All Programs, click Accessories, right-click Command Prompt, and then click Run as administrator.

segment.source: Navigate to %windir%system32inetsrv.
segment.target: Navigate to %windir%system32inetsrv.

segment.source: Type appcmd.exe set config -section:system.webServer/security/authentication/windowsAuthentication -useAppPoolCredentials:true, and then press ENTER.
segment.target: Type appcmd.exe set config -section:system.webServer/security/authentication/windowsAuthentication -useAppPoolCredentials:true, and then press ENTER.
